story: Merged a candle‑maker and soap‑maker at their father‑in‑law’s suggestion in 1837.
Bill Hewlett & Dave Packard started in a Palo Alto garage in 1939 after flipping a coin for naming rights.
Steve Jobs sold his VW van and Wozniak sold a calculator to fund the Apple I in 1976.
Jeff Bezos left his job in 1994 and launched an online bookstore from a garage in Bellevue.
When broke in 2008, founders sold Obama‑O’s cereal boxes to support their business and get into YC.
Apoorva Mehta delivered beer to YC partner to get into Y Combinator in 2012.
Launched in the dot‑com boom and bootstrapped surveys with little funding.
Founded in the first dot‑com boom, stayed minimal and profitable with under 50 employees.
Dating site launched in 2003 and sold for $575M without major redesigns.
Bootstrapped SaaS company built to rival Oracle/Salesforce with millions of users.
Raised $80K on credit cards in 2007 to start data‑backup business, later IPO’d.
Started with $10K in 2004, waited eight years to raise first VC.
Founders created fake posts themselves in 2005 to seed engagement.
Idea sparked in 2008 when founder ran out of dog food and wished someone could fetch it.
Co‑founders launched ‘Uber for barbershops’ after failing with direct consumer app.
Apoorva Mehta built on Instacart success to enter healthcare in 2022.
Binny & Sachin started e‑commerce in 2007 from their apartment with ₹6000 pooled capital.
Marc Benioff’s side hustle VC wins $600M when Wiz got acquired by Google.
Steve Jobs bought and funded it after being ousted from Apple in 1985.
Jobs founded NeXT in 1985 after leaving Apple; later bought by Apple in 1996.
Palo Alto garage where HP launched is now considered the birthplace of Silicon Valley.
TaskRabbit pivoted from errands request site founded in Boston in 2008.
Founders built a platform in 2012 to connect U.S. manufacturers with designers.
Built by Maker’s Row cofounder in 2019 to help users manage debt and build wealth.
Survived the dot‑com crash by focusing on durable survey tools.
Phone networking bootstrapped to $30M ARR before acquisition.
Founded in 1999 to manage clinical data, later grew to $320M annual revenue.
Began as a business‑card printer during the dot‑com and steadily scaled.
Launched ride‑hail in 2009 but faced major culture crisis in 2017.
